sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs
Detects execution of "csc.exe" to compile .NET code. Attackers often leverage this to compile code on the fly and use it in other stages.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: PowerShell Script With File Upload Capabilities
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell scripts leveraging the "Invoke-WebRequest" cmdlet to send data via either "PUT" or "POST" method.

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with CRLF, LF line terminators

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The code appears to be a PowerShell script that defines a function called "RemoteFileManager". The function contains several sub-functions that perform various operations related to file and directory management. These operations include retrieving drive and path information, deleting files and directories, renaming files and directories, creating directories, executing commands, compressing files and directories into ZIP archives, and downloading files from a server.

The code also includes the definition of two structures (_OP_CODE and _RC4_KEY) and imports the necessary types from the System, System.Diagnostics, System.Runtime.InteropServices, and System.Security.Principal namespaces.

The script establishes a TCP connection with a server specified by the IP address and port number. It then enters a loop where it communicates with the server by sending and receiving packets of data. The specific behavior of the script depends on the opcode received from the server.

Overall, the code appears to have functionality related to remote file management and communication with a server. However, without further context or information about the intended use and purpose of the script, it is difficult to determine its true nature and whether it is being used for malicious purposes.

This code appears to be a remote file manager that can receive commands from a server and execute them on the local machine. It establishes a TCP connection with a specified IP address and port, and then sends and receives encrypted packets of data using RC4 encryption. The code can perform various operations such as getting a list of drives, listing files and directories, deleting files and directories, renaming files and directories, creating directories, downloading files, executing commands, and uploading files. It also handles requests to close the connection or remove the client. The code uses a unique identifier generated from the MAC address and IPv4 address of the local machine to identify itself to the server.

The code contains comments that provide some information about its functionality, but it does not include any documentation or explanations of the specific logic or algorithms used. It also does not provide any security measures or error handling, making it vulnerable to potential attacks or unexpected behavior.
